title: U.S. Found Not Liable for Puerto Rico Bond Losses
sub_head: A Washington judge rules against bondholders seeking to hold Uncle Sam responsible for losses on a $3 billion bond
body:
The U.S. government isn’t liable for losses on $3 billion in Puerto Rico pension bonds, a federal judge said Monday, rejecting efforts to put U.S. taxpayers on the hook for compensating investors.
Judge Richard A. Hertling of the U.S. Court of Federal Claims said bondholders can’t hold the U.S. government responsible for losses they may incur in the court-supervised restructuring of Puerto Rico’s debts. A federally appointed oversight board has been steering that restructuring since 2016, part of a broader push to rehabilitate the U.S. territory’s public finances.
The board has proposed deep write-downs on the pension bonds, sold in 2008 to prop up Puerto Rico’s failing public pension system. They are a relatively small slice of the roughly $125 billion pile of bonds and pension obligations that drove Puerto Rico to file the largest-ever municipal bankruptcy in 2017.
Judge Hertling’s ruling dismissed a lawsuit filed by Oaktree Capital Management LP and other bondholders accusing the U.S. government of illegally taking their property.
Oaktree declined to comment. Representatives for other bondholders didn’t respond to a request for comment.
